item.title: The Counselor Who Has Walked Many Miles In A Refugee's Shoes
item.description:
September 6, 2017 - His name is Ahmad Chahabi, he fled Syria for Berlin and now he's building a new life by helping other refugees.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/06/548624782/the-counselor-whos-walked-many-miles-in-a-refugees-shoes
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Houston Methadone Clinics Reopen After Harvey's Flooding
item.description: September 6, 2017 - Hurricane Harvey disrupted treatment for people addicted to opioids. Many need to get connected to a specialty clinic that can provide medication-assisted treatment.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 6, 2017 - Hurricane Harvey disrupted treatment for people addicted to opioids. Many need to get connected to a specialty clinic that can provide medication-assisted treatment. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/06/548819207/houston-methadone-clinics-reopen-after-harveys-flooding

item.title: Chastened Lawmakers Aim For Small, Bipartisan Health Care Victories
item.description:
September 5, 2017 - Senate Republicans and Democrats are trying something new on health care. It's called cooperation.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/05/548676514/chastened-lawmakers-aim-for-small-bipartisan-health-care-victories
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 5, 2017 - Senate Republicans and Democrats are trying something new on health care. It's called cooperation. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/05/548676514/chastened-lawmakers-aim-for-small-bipartisan-health-care-victories

item.title: Whatever Happened To ... The Mission To Get Rid Of Rwanda's Dirt Floors?
item.description: September 5, 2017 - A small project started in 2014 to replace dirt floors, which can make people sick, with sealed earthen floors. Demand has only grown — but not exactly in the way the CEO had imagined.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 5, 2017 - A small project started in 2014 to replace dirt floors, which can make people sick, with sealed earthen floors. Demand has only grown — but not exactly in the way the CEO had imagined. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/05/547407906/whatever-happened-to-the-mission-to-get-rid-of-rwanda-s-dirt-floors

item.title: In A Case That Is 'Almost Impossible,' Girl Dies Of Malaria In Italy
item.description: September 5, 2017 - "It's a mystery," said one health official. Italy was declared malaria-free in 1970. Officials will try to determine how and where the 4-year-old was infected.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 5, 2017 - "It's a mystery," said one health official. Italy was declared malaria-free in 1970. Officials will try to determine how and where the 4-year-old was infected. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/05/548624097/in-a-case-that-is-almost-impossible-girl-dies-of-malaria-in-italy

item.title: A Doctor Who Weathered Katrina Now Tends Victims Of Harvey
item.description: September 5, 2017 - Dr. Ruth Berggren spent six days struggling to keep patients alive in in New Orleans' Charity Hospital after Hurricane Katrina hit. She's now caring for evacuees from Hurricane Harvey.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 5, 2017 - Dr. Ruth Berggren spent six days struggling to keep patients alive in in New Orleans' Charity Hospital after Hurricane Katrina hit. She's now caring for evacuees from Hurricane Harvey. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/05/548626760/a-doctor-who-survived-katrina-now-tends-victims-of-harvey

item.title: Scanning The Future, Radiologists See Their Jobs At Risk
item.description: September 4, 2017 - In a new series called "Is My Job Safe?" NPR looks at the future of jobs at a time of rapid gains in artificial intelligence and robotics. We start with a high-paying job in medicine: radiologists.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 4, 2017 - In a new series called "Is My Job Safe?" NPR looks at the future of jobs at a time of rapid gains in artificial intelligence and robotics. We start with a high-paying job in medicine: radiologists. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/09/04/547882005/scanning-the-future-radiologists-see-their-jobs-at-risk

item.title: Get Off The Couch Baby Boomers, Or You May Not Be Able To Later
item.description: September 4, 2017 - If you sit too much during middle age — at work and at home — your ability to exercise or even walk in late decades is at risk, a study hints. And, of course, your risk of heart disease climbs, too.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 4, 2017 - If you sit too much during middle age — at work and at home — your ability to exercise or even walk in late decades is at risk, a study hints. And, of course, your risk of heart disease climbs, too. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/04/547580952/get-off-the-couch-baby-boomers-or-you-may-not-be-able-to-later

item.title: Coca-Cola Offers A Sweet Quest: A Million Bucks To Replace Sugar
item.description: September 4, 2017 - The company is holding a contest to find a new and natural, low-calorie sweetener. The challenge comes at a time when many Americans are cutting back on sugar due to obesity and diabetes risks.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 4, 2017 - The company is holding a contest to find a new and natural, low-calorie sweetener. The challenge comes at a time when many Americans are cutting back on sugar due to obesity and diabetes risks. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/09/04/547315191/coca-cola-offers-a-sweet-quest-a-million-bucks-to-replace-sugar

item.title: Fall Weather Headed Your Way? Time For Flu Shots
item.description: September 4, 2017 - The American Academy of Pediatrics reminds us that shots — not a nasal spray — are the most effective way to protect kids 6 months and older against the flu.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 4, 2017 - The American Academy of Pediatrics reminds us that shots — not a nasal spray — are the most effective way to protect kids 6 months and older against the flu. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/04/547916216/fall-weather-headed-your-way-time-for-flu-shots

item.title: San Diego Declares Health Emergency Amid Hepatitis A Outbreak
item.description:
September 3, 2017 - The virus has killed more than a dozen people and sickened hundreds of others in San Diego since November.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/09/03/548299633/san-diego-declares-health-emergency-amid-hepatitis-a-outbreak
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Whatever Happened To ... The Plan To Jazz Up Jackfruit?
item.description: September 3, 2017 - In 2014, food researchers wanted to get more people eating jackfruit — a tree fruit chock-full of nutrients. How's that going?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 3, 2017 - In 2014, food researchers wanted to get more people eating jackfruit — a tree fruit chock-full of nutrients. How's that going? http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/09/03/547337695/whatever-happened-to-the-plan-to-make-jackfruit-more-popular

item.title: Pets Deserve Evidence-Based Medicine, Too, Says The SkeptVet
item.description: September 3, 2017 - Veterinarian Brennen McKenzie writes The SkeptVet, a blog that pushes for evidence-based medicine instead of relying on tradition, anecdotes or pseudoscience in the treatment of cats and dogs.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 3, 2017 - Veterinarian Brennen McKenzie writes The SkeptVet, a blog that pushes for evidence-based medicine instead of relying on tradition, anecdotes or pseudoscience in the treatment of cats and dogs. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/03/547420275/pets-deserve-evidence-based-medicine-too-says-the-skeptvet

item.title: Has Salt Gotten An Unfair Shake?
item.description: September 3, 2017 - For years, we've been told that less salt is better. But some scientists say that the world's universal seasoning has been maligned and that moderate salt intake is healthier for many people.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 3, 2017 - For years, we've been told that less salt is better. But some scientists say that the world's universal seasoning has been maligned and that moderate salt intake is healthier for many people. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/09/03/547827356/has-salt-gotten-an-unfair-shake-sodium-partisans-say-yes

item.title: The Chemical Dangers In Houston's Manchester Neighborhood
item.description: September 2, 2017 - The Manchester neighborhood in Houston is ringed by chemical plants. We went out with a team to test water and soil for toxins and other possible dangers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: September 2, 2017 - The Manchester neighborhood in Houston is ringed by chemical plants. We went out with a team to test water and soil for toxins and other possible dangers. http://www.npr.org/2017/09/02/548076049/the-chemical-dangers-in-houston-s-manchester-neighborhood
